description.narrative:
This is an EC funded project. The major challenge facing the two ministries is lack of fisheries experts to carry forward the ministry's mandate. According to the Minister of Fisheries in Somaliland there is a need for more personnel with expertise and knowledge in fisheries to be able to cover the geographical area of the coastline and to be able to train the personnel in fisheries#. There is a general lack of fisheries expertise and there is a high level of brain drain of fisheries experts from the ministry to Europe and other parts of the world. In addition, there is a lack of appropriate policies, regulations and training in fisheries and marine resources management for fisheries personnel in the ministry.
The ministry also lacks funding and finances to fulfill its mandate. Ministry of Fisheries has not been a government priority in terms of financing the ministry in Somaliland <(>&<)> Puntland. Lack of recognition of Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) by international community led to illegal fishing and dumping of toxic wastes along theSomaliland and Puntland coastline. The Somalia transitional road map contains measures that would address illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing.
The specific objective of the action is to strengthen the capacity of the Ministries of Fisheries and Marine Resources in Somaliland and Puntland and private sector to maximize and manage marine resources and environment through adoption of the following two approaches: 1. To build capacity of the authorities in Somaliland and Puntland to formulate and put in place improved policies, regulations and monitoring mechanisms to manage marine resources and the coastal environment. The resultant policies areto form the legal basis for the protection of the right of these areas of Somalia over their sovereign waters and their jurisdiction over the marine environment. 2. Strengthen the capacity of the Ministries of Fisheries in Somaliland and Puntland to put in place a favourable working environment for artisanal fishermen.

participating-org.narrative: In 2004 Oxfam Novib set up a Liaison Office in Nairobi, Kenya in order to support the Strengthening Somali Civil Society Program, at the request of the EU. This request was based on Oxfam Novib's work in Somalia to date, but intended to be more widely directed atthe entire civil society sector and the specific context in which it is operating in a post-conflict country. The program started with consulting local organisations in Somalia and Somaliland to get a complete picture of the sectors and regions where they are active, the challenges they face and the relationship between civil society, local political structures and the private sector. A program was then developed to strengthen the institutional development of Oxfam Novib's partners and those of other Oxfams, as well as a range of new NGOs. In the first year local consultants were trained in Somalia. They were then seconded to civil society organisations to build their capacity in financial and organisational management. Furthermore, workshops were organised on specific themes suchas human rights and the role of civil society in the Somali context. The Liaison Office is now going to support the expansion of the program, focussing on strengthening both organisation and project management, while facilitating more training in the fields of civic education, governance, human rights and women's rights, HIV and AIDS and child protection. Over the years, the Somalia Country Office has expanded its intervention on short term humanitarian response as well as development development interventions. In 2015/2016, a decision was reached to move the Country Programme operation, which was largely in Nairobi, from Nairobi to Hargeisa. The country office has a small office in Nairobi , Kenya and large operations office in Hargeisa, Somaliland.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to a sustainable livelihood
